content.name: Planetary
content.description: [Planetary](https://planetary.social) is a open source iOS secure scuttlebutt application.

content.text: Yes it's the same scuttlebutt network. You can use an invite to add folks but we don't yet support just pasting in an identity to add them. That's on our roadmap.
welcome back. We've been having a few troubles with updates. ;-(
Those look amazing.

### Planetary Release 0.9.16 (Build 186)

We've pushed out a new release of [Planetary](https://planetary.social). Here are a few updates from [the changelog](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md). 

There's a but we're trying to track down where the app dies in the background. Once we get that fixed we'll be going through and inviting folks who signed up for our mailinglist. Feel free to invite friends now: [https://testflight.apple.com/join/M9hPo1gA](https://testflight.apple.com/join/M9hPo1gA)

We're looking at working on performance and reliability for the next release. We created a link which right now only works on phones with the app installed for https://planetary.social/p/@identity that takes you to a user. We're looking at a hosted viewer at that same url for folks who don't have the app installed. This is about making deep linking possible. Right now we don't let you do internal message links within the app, but it's on our roadmap to add as well. 


### [0.9.16] - 2020-04-02
**Added:**
- New Planetary typeface.
- Share your profile link to the world.
- Loading animation for Notifications and Channels screens.
**Fixed:**
- Show alert dialogs when errors occur.
- Report handled errors.



### [0.9.15] - 2020-03-26
**Fixed**
 - Post button not appearing when undocking the keyboard.
 - Crash when downloading logs in iPad.
 - Empty log when downloading logs.
 - Crash when database repair fails.
 - Bad wording for number of replies in a post.



### [0.9.14] - 2020-03-25
**Added**
 - Show spinning wheel when processing new messages.
**Fixed**
 - Issue with reply count different than replies shown.
 - Avatars when mentioning someone were displayed incorrectly sometimes.
 - Avatar disappearing when switching tabs.
 - Performance issues with Notification screen.



### [0.9.13] - 2020-03-20
**Fixed**
 - Login is now more efficient.
 - Posted hashtags are now compatible with other networks.
 - Fix hashtags with - sign in the middle.
 - Channels screen is sorted by newest to oldest.



### [0.9.12] - 2020-03-17
**Added**
 - Now you can open your profile tapping on your profile photo.
**Fixed**
 - Syncing is now more efficient.
 - Posted images are now compatible with other networks, like Patchwork.
 - Fix bug that prevented using the app after opening an image in full screen.
 - If you happen to touch a link while you are scrolling, the app doesn't open the link anymore.



### [0.9.11] - 2020-03-10
**Added**
 - Redeem invitations: Do you want to follow a pub? Now you can now redeem invitations in Settings > Manage Pubs!
 - Switch to main net: The app now works in the main net, so expect to be prompted to logout and onboard again, otherwise the app won't work fine. Go to Settings > Advanced Settings and tap on Reset application and identity, or alternatively, go to Settings > Advanced Settings > Dangerous and powerful debug menu and tap on Logout and onboard.

**Fixed**
 - Performance improvements and minor bug fixes.

yeah, so planetary and scuttlebutt stores images, videos, audio and long posts as what we call [blobs](https://ssbc.github.io/scuttlebutt-protocol-guide/#blobs). They aren't sent over the network until somebody requests it, which is different from how your feed works which has an explicit store an forward system.

This isn't great because often your phone opens the app, posts the images, then you do something else. Apple will then kill the app in the background to save battery and memory. Unless somebody requested the image while you had the app open then it won't flow out over the network. It stays on your phone until you're running the app at the time somebody tries to view the image.

There are a few things we need to do to improve the way the images flow through the network. First we're switching from a polling model of connections to one where the connection stays open for bi-directional traffic. This will make images show up much faster. We do requests all blobs on our pub's to try and get them that way, but it doesn't always work. 

We've also looked at using something parallel to scuttlebutt for blobs like dat or ipfs, but we haven't gotten there yet.

# Funding the arts: a request for funds for artist grants

Hello, handshake council!
[@Zach!](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519) and I would like to roll out an initiative to invite artists to make art in the SSB space. The idea is to invite some folks to make SSB-inspired art, whether that's as a reaction to exploring the P2P space, culture, or the protocol itself.

We've got $628.68 euros in our discretionary fund at the moment. We would like to give each artist $500 euros to create something special in this space. If we support four artists in total, that comes to $2K euro, so **we are requesting $1,371.32 euros.**

Where should this come from? In [the current budget](%Mn/kVU4CeL4lweGCGgxg0BxixFRVZnkFVymzITQB6GE=.sha256), the "general buffer" has $6K in it. This would work nice! Or there another fund that everyone thinks would work?

A couple days ago #scuttlebutt was featured on #hackernews, a lot of [the discussion](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=22909984) centered around the way the current legacy feed encoding format signs json and doesn't support edit, delete, and private groups. We're working on that. First Planetary supports a new format that encodes the feed using CBOR instead of json, we're calling it, [GabbyGrove](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-spec-drafts/blob/master/drafts/draft-ssb-core-gabbygrove/00/draft-ssb-core-gabbygrove-00.md). Right now Planetary supports both the legacy format and the new ones, but we're still working on getting support in to the [node implementation of scuttlebutt](https://github.com/ssbc/). It's an open source project and the community would love contributions to fix things. 

In terms of privacy? Right now it's not fantastic once you're on the network most of the posts are public. We're working on [private groups](https://github.com/ssbc/private-groups-spec). That's what's really needed for planetary and scuttlebutt to live up to the promise of a fully decentralized open privacy aware social media protocol.

Hey [@Kenzo](@twmwAnbTCZjvYxPCFV6FW9QGeqVLFJiP6MDjML49aSY=.ed25519) ,

So [private messages in scuttlebutt](https://handbook.scuttlebutt.nz/concepts/private-message) are written to your log in something called a private box. The first message in the box is the box key encrypted once for each participant. Then each person who has access to the box uses the new keypair to write messages on the private thread. The messages themselves are encrypted and posted on each person's log. 

When your client gets an encrypted message it tries to decrypt it with it's keys. If it succeeds then you know it was for you. If you can't read it then it wasn't for you. This way you might know that your peer is writing private messages but not who they're communicating with. I'd say it's ok but not perfect metadata privacy. 

The encrypted messages do propagate across the peer to peer network but only the recipients can read them.

#### Planetary Update

We've released an updated version of [planetary](https://planetary.social/) with a bunch of updates under the hood. 
You can see the whole list of updates on our [changelog](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).  We've also renewed commitment to answer questions about where we're going with the app by flushing out the [product roadmap](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/wiki/Product-Roadmap).

The updates in of the bot, threads for syncing data, and db for loading data has made the user experience much better. It gets rid of the loading and processing message delays that we'd been dealing with. The work [@cryptix](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) has been doing on [go-ssb](https://github.com/cryptoscope/ssb) has been really promising and there's [more to come](%WPL1cXIi2eywXOWAnADzLFxmRul9JFA8wRAB8v/0nrI=.sha256). 

## [0.9.21] - 2020-05-10
### Added:
- New system for loading content so the UI updates faster and you can scroll back through history as far as you want.
- Changed the explore tab to show replies and new posts to help with discovering new content.

### Fixed:
- Fix bug where if you had more than 50 follows you wouldn't see new follows in your notifications tab.
- Changed Mixpanel actions to log user navigation through the app instead of just bot behavior. 
- Attaching GoBot logs to Share logs in Debug, to Bugsnag crash reports and to Zendesk tickets.
- Fix bug in background sync on notification of new content. 

## [0.9.21] - 2020-04-30
### Added
- All new Explore tab that shows posts from your greater network.
- New sync/refresh strategy that should be better at having your feed up to date.

### Planetary Release  0.9.27
This adds some social media niceness around liking posts and sharing them to other services. The big change is for new users, some feed data is bundled in the app so it's usable immediately while it starts syncing with the network.

cc [@graham](@LEkAGbzqsXLzBxLEPhkNluDHbPnkU6PXGyqwjqY10Tk=.ed25519)

Finally back to #moinho after 3 months away. Initial plans were to travel around indigenous communities, but #covid19 made us have to stop. Me and [@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) had to stay in a  agro-forestry farm, which at least was really nice, with really nice people.

Our #quarentine experience was probably the opposite of most, we were more outdoors then ever and closer to people then ever.

But it's good to be back, and put to use all we learned in #agroforestry for our land.

Donno about perma-guys acknowledging indigenous culture... that's the least they should do.

In Brazil permaculture is losing heat to the #agroforestry movement. But it also suffers from similar problems. The movement's god-figure is [Ernst Gotsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Gotsch), a Swiss farmer living here in Brazilian territory who "originated" these techniques... even though there are [many proofs](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/04/200408110336.htm) that pre-colombian peoples were responsible for converting savannas into what is today the amazon forest. Also never heard of this movement acknowledging indigenous peoples, instead indigenous peoples have been acknowledging the usefulness of  agroflorestry techniques.

It's good that indigenous ways of planting are being revived... but the fact that it's being credited to western people, and turned into western movements makes me believe they'll be too shallow, not encompassing the necessary systematic changes that are necessary for real shift to non-destructive ways of life.

### Planetary Release 0.9.27 (220)

This is a bug fix [release](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases) as we noticed that we were getting a number of crashes with 0.9.26 (217). This release also has a few cosmetic updates around loading blobs and providing content for new users when they first sign up. 

Added:
* We preload some feeds when onboarding so you donâ€™t have to wait to see something.
* Blob loading spinner.
* Load blobs from cloud as fallback.

Fixed:
* Crashes in the directory.
* Crashes when updating the database.

And for folks who want to chat with the planetary team, we've created [a matrix chat room](https://matrix.to/#/!kgNNtLPmJqLtvGAGKR:matrix.org/$mzSsXpZy-UVjx3wnnYW4_wCv9zxWVPZAdTg2TupvP04?via=matrix.org).

#### Moderation & Community Self Governance

Planetary is built on the idea that digital communities are governed best by their own communities. The creators of the platform shouldn't be expected to take on the impossible task of regulating speech, values, and norms. 

A really great model for this is emerging in the #scuttlebutt protocol we're using for #planetary. [@Tim Robinson](@Py8stqMfjhdc4Ln92R4Lg+3jITszP94G3P5BNuH+lWY=.ed25519) who wrote up [A TRUST AND MODERATION SYSTEM FOR THE DECENTRALIZED WEB](https://adecentralizedworld.com/2020/06/a-trust-and-moderation-system-for-the-decentralized-web/). A decentralized system in and of itself is not better. It'll be messy, but it will have the advantage of working the way most human systems worked. There will be conflict and politics. But what this system does is give us the fundamental building blocks of a well governed commons to build our digital publics.

# NodeMCU & YF-S201 Flow meter

Continuing from %o9GdsFm+tnqGrfSBufznKE7g5NY+l/SOsJ6ceAMYC1k=.sha256
 
## Getting started with the IDE

To get started with the [NodeMCU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NodeMCU) esp8266 development kit I first installed the [Arduino IDE](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software) and within it's "Board Manager" options added the [esp8266 core libraries](https://github.com/esp8266/Arduino). It comes with a bunch of example code to get us started.

I'm using Arch Linux and at first I had some permission problems while connecting to the NodeMCU's serial port thru USB, which were solved temporarily by following the instructions in [this issue](https://github.com/esp8266/source-code-examples/issues/26) and definitely solved by following the instructions in this [arch forum post](https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=211949).

When running the code I was having Java problems with the Serial Monitor, which were solved by changing my system's default Java version, as explained in [this issue](https://github.com/arduino/Arduino/issues/8903#issuecomment-497440283). 

Everything finally working, time to get started!

## Connecting the water flow meter

![arduino-water-flow-sensor-interface.png](&G/QzHmYP0S2XGsAk/RTdXaQqT5nSLBJSB9ucLhePxTM=.sha256)

The above image shows how to connected the [YF-S201](https://www.hobbytronics.co.uk/datasheets/sensors/YF-S201.pdf) to an Arduino, but with the NodeMCU it's the same principle. We connect the **RED** wire from the sensor to the *VU* pin in the NodeMCU, which outputs +5v; the **BLACK** to *G* (ground); and **YELLOW** to a GPIO pin, I chose *D2*.

It's a good idea to check the [NodeMCU pinout reference](https://www.teachmemicro.com/nodemcu-pinout/).

![NodeMCUv3.0-pinout.jpg](&dCtm8yPUB4azOy7t98w8LPzEYhRQ7bGY8Br+d9Ybupk=.sha256)
 
In our case the *D2* pin is GPIO4, so in the code I declare the pin as *4*.

## Upgrading the NodeMCU firmware

An important step is to upgrade the NodeMCU with the latest firmware, in order to make sure the firmware has all the libraries we'll be using. The [official firmware repo](https://github.com/nodemcu/nodemcu-firmware) has all the instructions.

[Nodemcu-build.com](https://nodemcu-build.com/) creates the firmware for us thru a friendly GUI and sends our specific build thru email. It sends two flavors, *Integer* and *Float*, basically just use *Integer* unless your code uses *floats*, [read here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40290307/nodemcu-integer-vs-float-firmware-what-is-different) to better understand the difference. Here's my firmware for reference:

[nodemcu-master-11-modules-2020-06-21-00-25-33-integer.bin](&fPOVEeL/d7dvfW+3uKov7zJ6sEbp//jPsH5AxuMco3Y=.sha256) 

Next I used the [NodeMCU PyFlashed](https://github.com/marcelstoer/nodemcu-pyflasher) to easily flash the module using a GUI. If using the terminal is your thing, there's also the [esptool.py](https://github.com/espressif/esptool) tool.

## Coding

[This instructables](https://www.instructables.com/id/Flowmeter-NodeMcu-Counting-Litres/) guide is a great and has a simple to read code example on how to get some readings from the meter, connect to an access point and send a *HTTP GET* to a server with the data.

I did have some problems with the code, and had some debugging to do, but finally manage to get it working. The author's using the [thingspeak IoT platform](https://thingspeak.com/) to collect the data, so I signup and got some API keys to get the example working. Here's my final code for reference:

 [water_manage.ino](&ufxwb4LebhyaOlt43Hja2LeRwg7zzZXApeD2NuooqpI=.sha256)

And finally:

![video:nodemcu_water_flowmeter.webm](&0+0ZDlj2/XX4/I6AGwC1b05L3h0t6qCMqrTZrjpQ9V0=.sha256)
ðŸŽ‰ ðŸŽ‰ ðŸŽ‰

[@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) is blowing into the flow meter to simulate water flowing. You can check the live chart [here](https://thingspeak.com/channels/1085945/charts/1?bgcolor=%23ffffff&color=%23d62020&dynamic=true&results=60&type=line&update=15). Basically it shows the test I did last night, and this morning.

In production we'll most probably be sending data to our #moinho-mesh #community-server, and make an interface to publicly display the charts, as [comuREDE](http://comurede.net/) has done.

## Next steps

I'm eager to start playing with the [esplorer IDE](https://esp8266.ru/esplorer/) which let's us code in [Lua](https://www.lua.org/), as I'm way more familiar with it from my #libremesh experience. Luckily the instructables tutorial has also shared some Lua code.

The Chapada do Veadeiros region is known for it's UFO and alien culture. I personally had never had any sightings in 7 years. Last night was crazy though...

A star-like objects, but with a reddish light,  were disappearing and re-appearing in different parts of the sky. But nothing seemed to be moving.

In the middle of the night me and [@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) woke up, the sky was clear. Our room has a 4mx2m glass door, from which we see the night sky while going to sleep, and the sunrise when waking up. Immediately I saw a star like object zig-zagging across the sky, and disappearing. For about two hours these kept appearing at random parts of the sky and disappearing.

When I closed my eye to get some more rest, with them closed I noticed something bright. When I opened them, there was a really really bright star-like object, which wasn't there before. It had a really strange glow to it, sometimes getting brighter and sometimes dimming. It stayed there until I got to sleep, close to sunrise.

I'm not a UFO aficionado, but hard to dismiss an experience like this.

I hear ya [@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519)!

I'm personally a dreamer, and I don't mind dreaming as far as I can, even knowing that most probably those won't come true, cause these dreams aren't just for this life-time, I know in next life I'll keep on working towards these dreams, as I feel I've been working towards dreams from past incarnations.

I've also learned that the farthest you dream, the farthest you get, even if you don't realize the dream. Believing death is not the end is my way to keep on doing this without getting frustrated. And it's been working, many things I've dreamed a few years ago have become reality, which make me want to dream even further.

What is reality any way? Many cultures believe what we call "reality" is actually the dream, and the dream is actual reality ðŸ›©ï¸

We use the #go-ssb implementation and it schedules differently than the js one. Our hope is the next release will fix this problem.

Yeah [@Tanuva](@wUkBCZBKHHQHHMZU2Fnj/BXwq8DEn32TeMVbaId+he4=.ed25519) it's really a problem which we're working on. Both we don't want to show you the notification until you can see it and we want to make them show up much faster.

At Planetary we believe in controlling your data and running your own infrastructure. [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) has done a ton of [work on the go-ssb](%UhK5bsuXrhuyYMNNSbEzW0Rw+MkWWdIKa1dVf0Rtqr4=.sha256). We're using it both in the app and on our cloud pubs to provide connectivity.  Now we've got the [mooncake pub](%qfqUf3+dLfmyFC9kZUIA99E5s5qch/VSJBP9mSHP588=.sha256) by [æœˆå…‰è™¹](@g6c1/Zywct6TZsff4z26g24ax5HYmGvun7e3qT/yIPg=.ed25519). It's a project to make it easy to setup and run pub's using #go-ssb on micro servers.
Ghost has some good tools for self hosted email / blog / website services.

### Planetary Release [0.9.28](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases/tag/0.9.28)

Big release of Planetary. [@Sebastian Heit](@a+PqJTSfL3nZjmU5/MNWuAFRqHQAZgb5qQ0jGlxurPE=.ed25519) redesigned the explore tab in the app to make it easier to see discover new posts from your extended network.  We added the ability to see when the last sync with peers happened and trigger a new sync. We also noticed that our UI for liking was a ðŸ‘ but now it's a heart â¤ï¸. Full emoji reactions is still on the roadmap. 

![Screen Shot 2020-06-30 at 1.00.19 PM.png](&8FGPJStREZduN5E+BEEzHW5e/Vfca0BQzyXI434garw=.sha256)
![Screen Shot 2020-06-30 at 1.01.05 PM.png](&LyC+o07U+w3cwUGkCQkev9nTQ3zOjM6NxbApBEYABpo=.sha256)

[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) did [a bunch of work](%UhK5bsuXrhuyYMNNSbEzW0Rw+MkWWdIKa1dVf0Rtqr4=.sha256) on #go-ssb to add support for deletes to the core library. When you block somebody it now deletes that content from your device. We've started getting contributions from [@æœˆå…‰è™¹](@g6c1/Zywct6TZsff4z26g24ax5HYmGvun7e3qT/yIPg=.ed25519) on the go code base as well, they released an updated set of docs for [mooncake](%qfqUf3+dLfmyFC9kZUIA99E5s5qch/VSJBP9mSHP588=.sha256), a scuttlebutt pub using the go code base. Tweaks to the algorithm for choosing and reconnecting to pub's has really improved the user experience.

â€¢ Block users.
â€¢ Give hearts instead of liking a post.
â€¢ Tap the network status doodle to trigger a sync.

#### Fixed:
â€¢ Issues some users where having syncing the latest posts.  
â€¢ Improved request and loading of blobs.

# Autonomous Community Communication Dev-Diary âœŠ

Continuing from %lIbjvwjLq4hBknipechzRpNLCS2YTGhiDaBHmGDRCVs=.sha256

![moinho_torre_morro.jpg](&PYLBET5WT6iQ6R5w22Dob8/WorWsPSr/ThNUmW9RfqM=.sha256)

#moinho-mesh started from the opportunity given by the anarchist #ssbc-grants process, which happened in 2018. My personal goal was to make SSB accessible to my local community thus creating our own safe piece of cyberspace. Aridi, the main native collaborator, had the goal to expand the mesh network and have the best possible Internet access for the cheapest possible price. So the actual process happened in a very organic way, going to places where non of us initially intended, aggregating many collaborators during the years.

The previous diary ended with me leaving the village for 4 months. I was a very tired of being the network's central point (of failure), and so staying away seemed like a way for other nodes to assume their roles. This generated a larger crises then I was expecting, and almost meant the end of the experiment. But other peers stepped in and held the sky from falling. This was a great lesson for all of us, and gave us an opportunity for think about why is Rede Moinho (Moinho Network) useful and important for the community.

It's time to start a new diary, with new goals, which are more realistic and incorporates our 2+ years of experience as well as opinions and ideas from other peers who have joined our efforts.

## Goals

- Develop accessible services aimed at solving community needs
- Train community members on how to install/maintain/update communication nodes (servers, routers, newspaper, etc)
- Educate community at large on how to use and contribute to local services

## Initial links

- https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-server
- https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-portal

### Planetary Release 0.9.29 (226)

Big changes in notifications. They work as youâ€™d expect now. We had a bug where youâ€™d get notifications when our pub saw something for you and not when your phone found new notifications for you. This has been fixed and now notifications can work without any need for planetary servers and the content is always available when the notification is displayed.

Weâ€™ve also added an option to set if you want your content to be visible through the web gateways like [planetary.link](https://planetary.link) and [viewer.scuttlebot.io](https://viewer.scuttlebot.io/).


#### Added
* Create notifications locally
* Display notification in Notification Center
* Notify about replies to posts user replied to
* Add public web hosting option in Settings
* Add Share Public Identifier option

The scheduler for choosing what pubs to connect to is making really poor choices. If you redeem an invite to a pub it'll use that more often. The next release we've completely rewritten the scheduler and it should work much better.

# Connecting peoples of the Earth



For some years now I've had a growing urge to connect with my ancestry and the cultures of Earth, to help in any way I can with their resistance and learn the art of #buenvivir.

Last year's  [Kayapo Mesh](%tRXIdEOhhPhMf8ExbjsAquFPsLubCAyeGOi791QyDEQ=.sha256) project got lost in bureaucracies up until this day. This year I decided to do as I've done in the past, and go to the communities by my own means, with the goal of sharing the knowledge I had gathered in the past years in #communitynetworks and #distributedtech, but #covid19 stopped me.

But this year was awesome in the sense that I had the opportunity to connect to some key people who are fighting for indigenous cultures, and got to learn about a few different realities, even if remotely. Together we've been planning how to help communities and wrote a few communication/information related projects seeking funding.

## My current understanding of reality

![aldeias_br.gif](&hjNB6+UDQ4zUtkFpISQMNMXtNlLKaMdA76ynmKNOYVA=.sha256)
*Map with known indigenous communities and "official" territories within "brazilian" territory*

The yellow pins in the map above are a few of the known indigenous villages in brazilian territory, and the white areas are the "official", government sanctioned, territories. The relation between the presence of indigenous cultures and forest conservation is obvious.

The deeper within the forest villages are, the less likely they are to have communication, and most probable of being molested by loggers, miners and narcotic traffickers. Basic communication is a matter of survival for many. And besides only survival they **must** have the ability to speak to the outside world for themselves without depending on the state or NGOs (or myself for that matter) to speak for them. I personally also believe that giving them voice could inspire many out there who can't seem to grasp that there are alternatives to self-destructive systems.

Access to information is also crucial as most villages aren't 100% autonomous anymore, so they need to interact with the market for some basics needs. They also make use of a wide variety of modern tools, which obviously break. Many times they're able to hack the tools and make use of them in some way, but many other times the tools become obsolete, so access to technical knowledge is fundamental.

## Secure, low cost, low energy communication and information technologies

There have been amazing projects that have connected remote forest areas, such as [Rhizomatica's Hermes](https://www.rhizomatica.org/hermes/) which uses HF radio. But HF equipment is still way too expensive, energy consuming (many villages don't have electricity) and requires a ham-radio license, which makes it not scale at the pace which is [urgently](%4nTDVO9ZxZGFYNCGYnnIBLUmc3DpBBKZskbygRuwhos=.sha256) needed.

I've been really into #electronics lately, and been obsessed with the idea of building non-corporate communication/information devices. So I've been investigating #lora a lot, and how it's perfect for such remote cases, at least as a first option until high-bandwidth communication reaches them.

A single-board computer loaded with applications such as #manyverse, #ahau, #mapeo and #kolibri would serve the purpose of giving access to at least some pre-loaded information, and delay-tolerant communication of large files.

Combined these technologies offer a cheap, low energy, low tech barrier initial solution that might scale.

## My Dream

![nodes_rionegro.jpg](&2c/C6npkznEJV4G9bZl43oo22teNGm/uZUcCDsKCGfE=.sha256)

I've been using [this tool](https://link.ui.com) to locate hills near important Amazon rivers, which are likely to also have communities in the need of communication/information tech. Still need to do lots of experimentation, but I think that such LoRa mesh would be feasible.

I can't stop dreaming on going on an expedition *a la* [Schultes](https://www.amazonteam.org/maps/schultes/en/) (lol) in order to connect peoples of the Earth not only to the world, but most specially to connect them with each other and other originary cultures around the world. That's where I see the potential for great change.

I'll keep on experimenting, just wanted to throw this here, as SSB has a magic that makes dreams come true ;)

Errata: when I talk of cultures of the Earth, I actually mean cultures of Mother Nature. From:
> We know that Mother Nature has a culture, and it is a Native culture
> Yupiaq scholar, Oscar Kawagley

One could claim every culture is of planet Earth, but I'm not referring to the dead stone sphere floating on space.

# Community Local Market

### 12/08/2020

[APC](https://www.apc.org/) granted #moinho-mesh $2900 USD for us to conduct emergency activities in our community. This may not seem as much, but the with the USD being valued over 5x the BRL, it's a significant amount, specially in a small village such as ours. The writing of this small project was done mainly by a group of women from the village who have been involved in organizing and maintaining a local solidarity market in the form of a WhatsApp group.

The planned activities need to be conducted by the end of the year, starting next week. Based on our 2 years experience, we decided to focus less in technology and more on educating and involving the community. As we've been too focused on technology our group hasn't been very diverse, with mostly men. So this time we have diversity as a core value, aiming to have at least 50% women and at least 50% natives. We'll be organizing an open call for anyone who would like to be involved in the activities to apply and work with us. The areas we'll be working on are: technology (mesh network, [community-server](https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-server), [community portal](https://github.com/moinhodigital/community-portal)), communication (documenting the process and creating a monthly newspaper) and community research (gathering economic data and educating on the use of the app).

I'll be updating the [community portal](https://moinho.network/) to include a local market page, which is built with [Gridsome](https://gridsome.org/) to make it easy to edit with Markdown. I'll be teaching at least two other people from the village on how to maintain and update the app. I'll be spreading local-servers (Router running LibreRouterOS + Single-board computers donated by [@benhylau](@Ys9lgBLC0MfPUQrbqd0hddjbjElx7ZNvtikxvMIaqgs=.ed25519)) on key places around the village to guarantee the services to be accessible. The app will also be online, as most people already have Internet access.

Then every month a group will be going door-by-door showing people how to use this local market and asking them for goods and services they would like to include in it. They will also be responsible for researching public services from town which we have the right too make use of, such as doctors, dentists, social care, etc. A small local newspaper will be designed and printed monthly, and spread around the village and the town with all this info, to really guarantee accessibility even for those who aren't into digital devices.

In total we're planning to have around 15 people working with us a few hours a month and expected to positively impact the whole village and it's surroundings. Might seem a bit ambitious for such a small grant, but after 3 meetings our whole team feels pretty positive about it.

I've been keeping an eye on the work being done by [@pospi](@Oqa5JW8rwWIVLBu38KkIb1IYz6Ax0yHuwRvLEGR1mkY=.ed25519), [@bobhaugen](@iL6NzQoOLFP18pCpprkbY80DMtiG4JFFtVSVUaoGsOQ=.ed25519), [@Lynn Foster](@g0xA0PhPzNInPFwPq3VoKcx56KZ9PFqY0QiJnKXx3co=.ed25519), [@Mayel](@aTQuVwkglxM9TABZlDBk1NF4rqfe1v6yjyH+KFb3mPI=.ed25519), [@ivan](@XZckLAZUD7b+HzVuNN1IcRBt/H7Lh9rx//WOmzhBpTc=.ed25519) and others on #valueflows UI applications. Really hope to use it and collaborate in the future.

I've recently setup an [Open Collective for Moinho](https://opencollective.com/rede-moinho), in hopes of getting some micro-donations to keep our experiments going even without any grants. I think we need a #tiny-browser-coalition to talk about building tiny browsers. Our charter is to build as many tiny browsers as we can until our numbers eclipse the amount of hipsters who are into microbreweries. 

#microbrowseries are in, impossible-to-implement-specs are out.

Who else is building a small browser and want to chat?

cc #agregore [@RangerMauve](@tdeT1cU3xUQaD2Ne5Ox0Dndly50qS+c5+//Fl7tyPqg=.ed25519)

[@Stardust](@P2lREv/l9EuyFCyNAcTjLV5T25yXKJ3D5GoPtoJQ3Tc=.ed25519),

 > That seems to be interesting. Is preventing browser monopoly a goal?

Yes, it is on our charter under the _Impossible Goals_ section.

Now, honestly, there is no such thing as preventing browser monopoly anymore because no one can actually build a full web engine from unless they are filthy rich and have time machine. That boat has sailed. We can still create tiny browsers for more fun and nimble protocols though, and for subsets of the web.

[@Stardust](@P2lREv/l9EuyFCyNAcTjLV5T25yXKJ3D5GoPtoJQ3Tc=.ed25519),

* There used to be [XULRunner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XULRunner). This is the runtime in which Firefox, Thunderbird and many other projects were built with. Think of Electron but before Electron. It was initially released in 2006 and discontinued in 2015 with the move to the new Firefox stuff (there were good reasons for dumping it). The apps were built with a combination of web technologies and XUL which was another XML-based language to build interfaces.
* There was [positron](https://github.com/mozilla/positron) which was Electron but with Gecko instead of WebKit. It was also cancelled.
* There was [webrt](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Apps/WebRT) which was a runtime that allowed installing open web applications (aka the FirefoxOS apps) in macOS, Windows, Linux, and Android. It predates PWAs, and open web apps would appear in the desktop/android as their own app. It was cancelled and removed in 2016.

Mozilla has shipped many Electron alternatives over the years. Most of them predate Electron and many are (IMHO) better than Electron. It didn't work, they never got traction.

[@mark](@2uAvsruiAF9rFC20OUZWc/Da+6q1HqY0GQjwmyVUZ4w=.ed25519),

There is no wasm without first having a JS engine. Real-world wasm apps depend a lot on JS standard library. JS-in-wasm ends up with two garbage collectors running, you don't want that. Wasm is not yet ready for running dynamic-language interpreters.

If I was you I wouldn't target the web, or even a subset of it. It is really fun to work with other protocols. Check out #gemini and #gopher.

[@mark](@2uAvsruiAF9rFC20OUZWc/Da+6q1HqY0GQjwmyVUZ4w=.ed25519),

I find wasm really cool as well. Originally my thesis for my undergrad degree was a scheme to wasm compiler but I had to drop out and was never able to actually do it. I think that the thing that makes more sense for the job you described is implementing WASI which I assume you're already doing. It will be really cool to see some more wasm stuff in here.

As for Gemini being "in development", all protocols are in development as far as I am aware. I don't think Gemini will see much change in the near future, it is basically already good for what it proposes to do. The spec is damn easy, I could implement a passable browser in a single day, and then spend the whole next week fixing bugs in that code I hastily cobbled together on that fun day. I really recommend doing it. [@RangerMauve](@tdeT1cU3xUQaD2Ne5Ox0Dndly50qS+c5+//Fl7tyPqg=.ed25519) just added support for it in their Agregore browser and all the modules are open source, you might want to take a look as it is closer to the environment you're using than the stuff I am doing.

One cool thing about the Gemini ecosystem is that since it is damn easy to build there are a ton of mini clients, all of them open source and done in many different languages. I think that a Gemini client will become my _hello world_ sample for when I am learning a new language.

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) I like the idea of starting small and working these selected modules at first. In my mind the _ssb-js_ org needs to hold the basic modules required to make a bare client and server, that requires more modules than that. I'm expecting that if we can manage this initial modules that others will follow.

>  Even something like â€œwe have a repository with the member list and ground rules and patches donâ€™t get merged without 2/3 approvalâ€ would be fine by me, but Iâ€™m open to suggestions on this front as well.

I think that is a good initial workflow, to be honest we are not sure of what kind of workflow we need so I don't see the need to overcomplicate stuff before we actually know our real needs. I'm happy to start like that and then revisit the workflow once we have more experience as an org.

### Fafi has tabs and history now

![video:2020-08-20_12-58-43.mp4](&ZMg+8WTjnonPnWqely+D9LZ59gVEutPO5rjSwPSdKg8=.sha256)

Even though there are tabs in the interface, fafi uses a unified history queue. Most web browsers use a per-tab history but implementing that was more complicated and I didn't felt like doing it. The history dialog is bare-bones, it just displays the `history-backward` list. 

That dialog implementation uses only 34 lines of bad racket programming:

```lisp
#lang racket/gui

(define history-window
  (new frame%
       [label "History"]
       [width 400]
       [height 600]
       [x 100]
       [y 100]))

(define (new-tab) (void))  

(define list-box (new list-box%  
                      [parent history-window]
                      [label "Double click to open the URL in a new tab"]
                      [choices '()]
                      [style (list 'single
                                   'column-headers
                                   'vertical-label)]
                      [columns (list "URL")]
                      [callback (lambda (c e)
                                  (when (eq? (send e get-event-type) 'list-box-dclick)
                                    (define url (send list-box get-string-selection))
                                    (new-tab url)
                                    (send history-window show #f)))]))

(define (show-history-window history callback)
  (set! new-tab callback)
  (send list-box set (remove-duplicates history))
  (send list-box set-column-width 0 360 360 360)
  (send history-window show #t))

(provide show-history-window)
```

The main window calls `(show-history-windows history-backwards new-tab)`.

Back in February one of our investors in [Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) told me that #covid was a really big deal and that it was going to cause cascading failures in the supply chain. Of course industry and government officials reassured the public that everything was under control. Itâ€™s not. This pandemic was both entirely predicted and also a #blackswan out of nowhere event. We knew pandemics would happen but not the nature of the disease or when. So much of our economy is based on the idea that tomorrow will be like today. Once the norms fall apart what happens? How does that relate to Anglo-American millennialism which focuses on an impending collapse around every corner? 

I lived in Argentina during the 2002 economic collapse. The economy shrank by 75% in a single month. It was very hard on people, especially the middle class, but it didnâ€™t cause the everybody for themselves that Hollywood predicts. Instead there was a tremendous outpouring of humanity and mutual aid. Turns out that the normal human reaction to a crisis is humane and not selfish. So much so that Rebecca Solnit has documented that the reaction to a crisis is often considered a high point in peopleâ€™s lives due to that common purpose and support. If you havenâ€™t read it, I highly recommend her short book, [A paradise built in hell](https://books.google.com/books/about/A_Paradise_Built_in_Hell.html?id=JB-MDQAAQBAJ&source=kp_book_description).

### Planetary Release 0.9.30

This latest release is all about content updating and syncing. The planetary app was not prioritizing syncing with pubs based on their reliability and this was causing a user experience where content might not update for a while. With this release we've both tweaked the relay pubs we're running and how we prioritize connections. This is part of a larger effort to update and [release code](https://github.com/planetary-social/) for a faster & more efficient set of peer to peer libraries. 

#### Changelog:
* Subscribe to new pubs
* Create a Pubs table
* Remove old pubs
* Always check the redeemed pubs before syncing
* Refactor operations during onboarding
* Create Mission Control Center to manage missions
* Add logging and clean tests
* Fix Unit Tests
* Update Github Actions config file

As always, if you're using Planetary, and you want to upgrade, go in to the apple TestFlight app to update things.

I think itâ€™s important to fight on this front but also, as youâ€™d imagine being here, build autonomous alternatives.

Yeah, so [@wakest](@89cCJmBp7Oq/JewbOTjUQtXxB6QsHsCNVrCr5OIU5mU=.ed25519) the syncing works much better now. This was in a big shift in [how we managed pubs and connections](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/commit/a216cdf9eae3faa87d2f2891992e0626a383fcef). We added new pubs to the planetary network, switched to using invites instead of a followback api, so you don't need an internet connection, and created a pubs table in the local db which tracks invites, and some connection status history. 

The next release will include our rewrite of [peer discovery](https://github.com/planetary-social/swift-peer-discovery) and [gossip](https://github.com/planetary-social/swift-gossip) putting it in the swift code. There's some apple libraries for mesh networking which meant we needed to do it in swift, or it was easier anyway. We also found that just debugging between go and swift was tricky. So the more network stuff we needed to work on, the easier it was to do in swift. Documentation will come for these libraries as well as packaging so people can use them in their own projects.

To be honest, I don't like docker at all but people seem to love it. You can think of it as a way to run a lightweight virtual machine. In theory I think one could ship all the code already setup to run git-ssb and ssb-npm, all the dependencies and whatever libraries it links with in an image. The user would provide their own ssb folder. 

This could be achieved with a FOSS solution like QEMU too. The only think I don't know is if git-ssb and ssb-npm rely on stuff inside flume to run, because in that case I don't think a virtual image will work. I'm not sure.

The main idea behind shipping an image is to make it easy to run things. It is a horrible kludge, in essence you're shipping a whole linux. I just mentioned this idea because it might minimize support requests like people with the wrong library versions, etc.

I don't think you should focus on this.

I've also got a new indigenous ally from the [KrahÃ´](https://pib.socioambiental.org/en/Povo:Krah%C3%B4) tribe. I visited a few of their villages back in 2016 with my mother and daughter, and now they're in real need for communication in the most isolated villages to resist #covid19. Just acquired these cute little toys. These [TTGO-T-Beam](https://github.com/LilyGO/TTGO-T-Beam) cost way more here then elsewhere in the world. I found them used for $ 42.50 USD each, with battery, case and screen included. Once I've learned the basics I hope to acquire more boards from Aliexpress for cheaper, but brazilian customs is a pain, and I've had stuff get stuck with them before, so a bit afraid to do that.

## Testing

First firmware I tried was [Meshtastic](https://www.meshtastic.org/), as this device seems to be made for it and they have ready-to-go [bin files](https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-device/releases). Installing everything was really straight forward, but I a hard time connecting the T-Beams to the phone app. But after trying a bunch I was finally able to a get a few messages thru, but my phone battery died before I could actually do some real range testing with them. I haven't been able to get two phones connected to it since. Opened an [issue](https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-Android/issues/137), and the main developer and maintainer for the project was fast in responding.

Next up I tried #sudomesh #disasterradio. Steps:
 - `git clone git@github.com:sudomesh/disaster-radio.git`
- Install platformio cli
- `cd firmware && pio run -e ttgo-lora32-tbeam -t upload -t uploadfs`
- modify `platformio.ini`'s `monitor_speed` to this boards speed: 921600
- `pio device monitor` to see the device logs

Seem to be getting something from the board:
```GPS fix type 3
Update DB node 0xabfa10d8, rx_time=1598463937
Node status update: 1 online, 1 total
New GPS pos lat=-14.xxxx, lon=-47.xxxx, alt=887, pdop=2.350000, heading=27790.964850, sats=7
```
Although Bluetooth lights on the board are blinking, I can't seem to be able to find it on the phone. I'm guessing the firmware I'm using is for the T-Beam V0.7, and there's no support for this [T-Beam v1](https://github.com/sudomesh/disaster-radio/issues/33) (?). Here a pic of the board:

*Qual.net* looks really awesome [@zenna](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519). But for this specific use case that I'm starting to journey into, the reliance on WiFi and even normal devices (phones and computers) don't fit. 

Geography has helped preserve these ways-of-life which present an alternative, thus are a threat, to the self-destructive *status quo*. But, as the forest that they depend on, they are under constant threat and are fragile, as the whole world seems to be "against" them. The geography that has protected them up until now present it's own challenges for resistance.

The concepts used by *Qual.net* and *SSB*, just to name a few, are amazing but need to be expanded to use other radio communication technologies such as LoRa or HF, and other devices such #disasterradio. Something ideal for this specific use case would be a disaster-radio + #peachcloud device. **Cheap, low-power, long-range**.

The work [@adria0](@ZFWw+UclcUgYi081/C8lhgH+KQ9s7YJRoOYGnzxW/JQ=.ed25519) and [@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519) are doing with SSB on micro-controllers are a huge step in that direction, I hope to join their efforts in the future. For now I'm experimenting with LoRa tech to learn of it's possibilities, as something as simple as text messaging could mean saving peoples lives, peoples cultures and peoples territories.

Yes of course I asked everyone bundled if they were ok with before I we did it. We donâ€™t auto follow the accounts but it seemed like a good way to show people some examples of users who reflect the community and how SSB is used by others. 

Ideally Iâ€™d like to have a script that preloads only a subset of their feed, like the most recent about messages and a few dozen posts. We donâ€™t really need the full history here. But partial feeds are a whole nuther issue.

And they're so remote, and deep in the forest that I can't imagine an [ANATEL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Agency_(Brazil)) agent going there to try and shutdown a node that isn't complying to national laws.

So this is a great opportunity to hack LoRa to be as efficient as possible, without giving a s*** to regulations (I love that btw, can you feel the excitement of me saying that?).

# World's Largest Coffee Tasting

![image.png](&dwukITrjXsC1yOM07rS3oHNxasBVTNa/R8sB+CTwllk=.sha256)

#### October 3rd, 3pm UK

James Hoffman, who has [an amazing YouTube channel about coffee](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ilY4EV9Qqs8), is going to be hosting a large at-home coffee tasting experience in October. 

Link: https://www.worldslargestcoffeetasting.com/

The kit costs 7 pounds and ships anywhere in the world (for a non-complete definition of anywhere). In the video I linked above, he is tasting coffee grown in the UK and later he tells a bit about this event. He has 50 kits to give away for those who can't afford to buy them and want to participate. In that video he has more info about the free kits.

I just purchased a kit and am already anxious for October 3rd.

Ok, my internet let me do some real research now. What I found about NRF52:

- On **Ultra Low Power Nodes**: This board should be able to do exactly what you describe even without having the mesh sleep (because the nrf52 and the sx1262 have absurdly low power draws while in receive mode). According to my spreadsheet his board should be able to run indefinitely as a â€œrouterâ€ with a quite small solar cell. So you could place one of these devices (discreetly) in a tree that has good line of sight for a region and it would happily route packets for that whole area (using just a tiny solar cell). [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/ultra-low-power-nodes/218/2?u=luandro)

- [Meshtastic airtime and current draws spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ft1bS3iXqFKU8SApU8ZLTq9r7QQEGESYnVgdtvdT67k/edit#gid=1182643433)

- It sounds like there are a couple of folks working on getting a NRF52 and/or sx1262 boards out. As soon as something like that exists I bet that will be the ideal repeater node (because super low power draw and better radio performance). [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/headless-base-station-repeater/363/2?u=luandro)

- **Global messaging support** (not really about the NRF52, but related to integrating SSB+LoRa): the appeal adding an optional internet gateway is so â€œwhenever some member of your mesh happens to connect to the internet, it will magically send/receive messages to/from any internet userâ€. [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/proposal-for-global-messaging-support/455/31?u=luandro)

I will drink any coffee. Styrofoam cup in a uni cafeteria? I'll have it. Fancy microlot from Hawaii? I'll have it too. Don't care, love them all. 

I like his videos though. Specially the ones where he teaches about how to make better coffee with the tools you already have such as v60 and aeropress. I enjoy the occasional review of equipment I'll never buy and when he tastes bad coffee and makes a funny face.

- **On the  Rak4600**: That looks like a great board. The existing nrf52dk target in meshtastic is almost exactly the same, so I bet adding it will not be too hard. # Fafi v0.9

âœ¨[binary releases](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/fafi-browser/refs/v0.9)
âœ¨[source-code](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/fafi-browser)

![image.png](&DNFYro0pBoC65tqNzyouiYdIbforzanDJxq8gOYZqY4=.sha256)
_Fafi rendering a RSS feed._

A lot has happened since the last release of #fafi-browser.  The feature that is most visible is that fafi can now render ATOM and RSS feeds as well. It is a simple text render with links, nothing fancy, but enough for you to check some gemlogs update.

### Technical stuff

I have decoupled network communication from rendering content. Fafi has _transports_ and _renderers_.

* **Transports:** these objects implement both `fetch` and `can-handle-url?`. If the latter is true, then that transport is used to fetch the URL. There are two transports at the moment, one for handling _gemini protocol_ called `gemini-transport%` and another to handle _http and https_ called `web-transport%`.
* **Renderers:** Are used to display content from the transports. They implement `can-render-mime?`, `set-content`, and `clear`. Using the `MIME` type from a successful `fetch` call, `multi-renderer` can ask all _rendersers if they can handle that mime, the first one who can is used to render the content.

Below is a cute Racket sample from the `image-renderer%`:

```lisp
    (define/public (can-handle-mime? mime content)
      (string-prefix? mime "image/"))
```

This is the first release in which I am attempting to generate binary distributable files. I've generated them for macOS and Windows. Generating for Linux is trickier because of shared library versions. I'm not so sure how to handle that.

# The first experiment

I've been in touch with our KrahÃ´ collaborator and he's really excited for the experiment. He has confirmed support from the community for lodging and food during my stay. Besides doing this experiment I'm hoping to introduce them to tools such as #mapeo, #ahau, #manyverse, #huiom and the #librerouter, which might be of use to them.

I've been thinking on driving there during the first two weeks of October. But until then, there are still tests to do, and an equipment list to define and buy. I'll be using my own savings, but hope to crowd-fund it back later on.

This is a first draft of the mesh plan we'll be attempting at their territory.

![link_LORA_manuelalves_serragrande.jpg](&SE34VdPdHUa4R22MCYNQ74Ro1Gm4xXJJz5h4KtDIVzo=.sha256)
*A mesh plan using 5 repeater nodes to bridge 2 villages that are 43.2Km away*

I've started to interact with the Meshtastic community thru this topic on their discourse channel: [Meshtastic to connect isolated villages](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/meshtastic-to-connect-isolated-villages)

They've been giving me good tips on antennas, solar setups and on how realistic such a mesh is. Good tips include using panel with 5V output in order connect it directly to the board to use less parts and have as few failure points as possible and using DIY omni antennas for the repeaters (looking at [this tutorial](https://youtu.be/1_1LxuOngHs)).

Here's the equipment list so far:
- [5x Heltec LoRa boards](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1645061816-5-x-placa-lora-esp32-display-oled-wifi-bluetooth-_JM)
- [5x 5W 5v panels with USB](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/carregador-solar-portatil-5w-com-usb-neosolar.html)
- [5x 2200mah 18650 batteries](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1180892186-bateria-18650-samsung-22p-original-2200mah-kit-4-_JM)
- [5x 18650 battery cases](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1210664880-kit-5-case-suporte-bateria-18650-para-1-bateria-37v-_JM)
- Copper for making DIY antennas (haven't found the ideal material for this yet)

All these are available here in Brasil. I'll be buying Moxon antennas and Rak4600 boards from Aliexpress, but won't be counting on them for this as things from China usually takes months to arrive (if they do).

## Test 1

Been learning to use an amazing tool for simulating radio coverage: [https://www.ve2dbe.com/rmonline_s.asp](https://www.ve2dbe.com/rmonline_s.asp)

Got a few of the settings from [this thread](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/how-to-fill-in-coverage-details-on-ve2dbe-com), but still feel it's not exactly right. Any tips are welcome.

This is the test I'll be attempting in the next few days, communicating between the two T-Beams over 7,44Km using the Meshtastic app.

# Test 1

Just did a test, placing a T-Beam on top of the hill where the main #librerouter node in #moinho-mesh sits.

![lora_torre_moinho_teste1.jpg](&KADPrUXxB09s7D30ZtGXFo5GpJOzHEr7zvrEYcEa33Q=.sha256)

The green area is the expected reach using the simulation. Unfortunately I didn't have the map with me to check exactly where to get the best signal in the nearby town (Alto ParaÃ­so de GoiÃ¡s), so I drove to the wrong places to test. The green and red lines are where I drove and got signal (green ðŸ’š ) or not (red ðŸ”´ )

But I was very surprised with these results, I was expecting to climb a hill to get a message through, but from inside the car messages were being sent no problem (using the maximum range/lowest speed settings). Within #moinho I got a connection everywhere.

# Star network

Based on the simulation for the KrahÃ´ territory I've decided to change strategies, and go for the best spot on the whole territory, making possible for all villages to connect. The trick here is to either have a really good omni:

![lora_kraho_central_nodes_omni.jpg](&TJC7z0l/OJlKDh1LlsokyrmQLEvq5RUBcGRdbJsQR14=.sha256)

Or place two nodes at the 435m high hill, each one with a yagi, which might be more guarateed to work, but would require placing more nodes at the center in case villages in the other directions want join the network:

![lora_kraho_central_nodes_yagi.jpg](&AtCn4UM5WsnzaNds/a5ErkNWAnXtY/AlmcxCqrOMJ+w=.sha256)

Probably worth testing the two options, by first placing nodes at the villages, then going up the hill and testing omni and yagis.

Almost decided on the kit I'll be going for, based on **simplicity** (for less points of failure), **price** and national **availability**.

- **5x** [5W pannel with 5V USB](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/carregador-solar-portatil-5w-com-usb-neosolar.html) - **R$ 110,00** (22.55 USD each)
- **5x** [TTGO LoRa](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1183694492-modulo-wifi-esp32-com-suporte-de-bateria-gps-e-lora-915mhz-_JM) - **R$ 220,00** (41.00 USD each)
- **1x** [Omni antenna](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-905740373-antena-omni-veicular-15-dbi-824-2600-mhz-_JM) (still not ideal, but only one I could find) - **R$ 325,00** (61.00 USD)
- **2x** [Yagi antenas](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1516947026-antena-externa-para-celular-18-dbi-806-a-960-mhz-_JM) (806-960mhz) - **R$ 107,00** (20.00 USD each)
- **5 meters of** [copper tubing](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1506079214-cano-cobre-38-para-tubulaco-gas-glp-ar-condicionado-split-_JM) (to test making antennas) - **R$ 127,00** (24.00 USD)

This is incredible resource [@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) ðŸ™ 

 [Beyond Line-of-Sight UHF Digital Communications with the LoRa Spread Spectrum Waveform.pdf](&0GrbSXzQqexXOCEybe5p9OMzRc0bAGEYjLAkvBGWi+U=.sha256)

Bits I found relevant:
- troposcatter allows for communications up to about 700km (using LoRa), with diffraction being limited to even shorter distances
-  they require a substantial link budget that requires high receive sensitivity, high transmit power, and high antenna gain
- diffraction is generally useful for shorter distance BLoS
- at longer distances, troposcatter provides BLoS propagation by scattering radio waves off irregularities in density and moisture in the upper troposphere. Troposcatter is a reliable communication method, but its effectiveness does vary based on weather conditions and can suffer from fast fading issues
- total path loss is at least 160-170dB for troposcatter communications
-  the 915MHz product and the 433MHz product align with the 70cm and 33cm amateur bands respectively.
-  the 433MHz product was used mainly to leverage the abundance of 70cm amateur radio
equipment, including low-cost antennas and power amplifiers; and feedline losses are lower on
lower frequencies
- [Halo antenna on the cheap](http://www.kr1st.com/70cmstack.htm)
- [Yagi antenna on the cheap](http://wa5vjb.com/yagi-pdf/cheapyagi.pdf)
- [LoRa airtime calculator](https://www.loratools.nl/#/airtime)

For the specific case of the KrahÃ´ territory, in the savanna, the geography and vegetation are blessings, so having a node at the center enables communication in most parts of the territory. But troposcatter is very relevant for the Amazon region. The amplifier might be the trick, as they seem to be a bit pricey and doing a quick search I can't even seem to find one in Brazil.

Well, enough about my love of butter and salt, let's move on to the book I was reading. I picked this book basically in a dare with myself. The book is called [Gideon The Ninth, by Tamsyn Muir](https://beta.thestorygraph.com/books/79fe8ae2-bed5-4156-a2af-685f656d57d3) and it was described by Charles Stross as:

Today I decided to use some time to implement a _preferences_ system for #fafi-browser. It turned out quite simple but useful for other people developing Racket apps:

```lisp
#lang racket/base

(require racket/file)

(provide (all-defined-out))

(define data-folder (let ([data-f (simplify-path
                                   (build-path
                                    (find-system-path 'pref-dir) 'up "fafi-browser"))])
                      (begin
                        ;; DANGER: side-effect
                        (make-directory* data-f)
                        data-f)))

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; PREFERENCES SYSTEM
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
(define preferences-file (build-path data-folder "fafi.rktd"))

(define (set-pref name value)
  (put-preferences (list name)
                   (list value)
                   #f
                   preferences-file))

(define (get-pref name [default-value #f])
  (get-preference name
                  (lambda () default-value)
                  'timestamp
                  preferences-file))

(define (set-default-pref name default-value)
  (let ([v (get-pref name 'unset)])
    (when (equal? v 'unset)
      (set-pref name default-value))))

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; Default preferences
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(set-default-pref 'homepage "gemini://gemini.circumlunar.space")



;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; MAIN (just help testing stuff)
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
(module+ main
  (displayln data-folder)
  (displayln preferences-file))

```

Using it from the `preferences-window%` of Fafi is damn easy.

```lisp
(define homepage-field
  (new text-field%
       [label "Homepage"]
       [parent panel]
       [init-value (get-pref 'homepage)]))
```

At the moment I don't have much to persist on the app, so the preferences window look quite empty:

![image.png](&q6aKE+2VbzuHGQD/rT1+a/X1zK0uovux10Ok0xUPnis=.sha256)

This coding session and its results serve as practice to implement the bookmarking system which will have a novel feature: It will allow you to track a URL so that you're notified if the content of that URL changes. The main use case for this is subscribing to RSS and ATOM feeds and tracking gemtext pages that are used like blog indexes.
[@Cameron Leslie](@2dtfbuH7XvPVNQvHcEIwwz89XbcobYceIQvvhpA5UZM=.ed25519) just style :-) at least with racket language, other bundled languages might treat it differently.

[@Cameron Leslie](@2dtfbuH7XvPVNQvHcEIwwz89XbcobYceIQvvhpA5UZM=.ed25519) so, don't know how familiar you are with [Racket](https://racket-lang.org) but at the top of the file there is a _language identifier_ which declares in which language the source code is. Racket ships with a dozen languages inside. In that code sample I'm using `#lang racket/base` which a subset of Racket, makes it quicker to launch that script since it doesn't need the full power of all Racket. Racket ships with languages that don't look like Racket, for example:

**Datalog:** Which is a logic programming language.

```
#lang datalog

ancestor(A, B) :- parent(A, B).
ancestor(A, B) :-
  parent(A, C), ancestor(C, B).
parent(john, douglas).
parent(bob, john).
ancestor(A, B)?
```

# First prototypes

## Extra LoRa boards, batteries and cases arrived ðŸŽ‰ 

### Boards âœ…

![krahÃ´_kit.jpg](&e2As8ef6kKatL6gom+Ke5k4za3CPEKL3o80c/0HLIA0=.sha256)

The boards were a good surprise, in that they were all T-Beams, which are the favorite boards for #meshtastic
firmware to run on. Installed and tested all of them, and they are working fine. Also my good friend Tiago helped me solder the little OLED screens onto the first two boards, and the ui/ux is actually quite amazing for such a small display and set of buttons.

### Batteries âŽ

![18650_sizes.jpg](&UjqN72DtqeTs337luUDDIYTBy/kfxW49DpMNIdBFLFs=.sha256)

I didn't know there were different sized 18650 batteries, and the ones I bought are about 2mm larger then the usual one, and don't fit on the T-Beams. Gonna return these.

Went on to buy [these hopefully original Sanyo 2600mah batteries](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1391705233-kit-com-8-bateria-sanyo-com-terminal-ur18650-37v-2600mah-_JM). Real challenge finding original, good quality batteries in Brasil.


### Cases âœ…

![krahÃ´_node.jpg](&K7+Z/5pe5aC9Qa+vZ5F6irdLpu6g4+MwSrOIkNHQBwA=.sha256)

When I first saw the cases I thought they would be too small. But it turns out that they fit perfectly by putting the boards diagonally. We drilled two holes on it, one at the top for the antenna, sealed with rubber for now (probably with silicon in the future); and one at the bottom, sealed with epoxy for the usb cable, which will connect to the solar panel, or for the first experiment to the usb of a #librerouter.

## Mesh experiment

While the panels and the yagi antennas don't arrive, I'll place one node where our LibreRouter is at the top of the hill, where on the [previous test](%c+yMaH7gYXWvdXauQVTCvl3YX97G62TD+yr6PtQBXbE=.sha256) we managed to get a connection anywhere in the village.

I'll keep one node, and give other nodes to neighbors around the village, and test out our own offgrid chat.

> Is there a core of goodness in there somewhere thatâ€™s worth saving?

The web is wonderful. I like this overcomplicated VM. It is full of amazing powers. Stop and imagine for a second, which other piece of tech is cross-platform like the web? You have clients viewing web apps on their iPads and on Amigas. It is also retrocompatible, you can load a website from 1998 without much trouble. And you can link across platforms and ages. It is an amazing stuff! The spec might be shit to implement but it is golden shit! 

Now, what I see as the problem is that the companies pushing the web forward don't share the same reality as the rest of us. FAANG are dealing with problems of a different nature that doesn't affect most players on the web. Instead of solving some of those problems in a way that everyone can participate — such as solving scalability with p2p — they solve it in a way that makes sense for their _behemoth-that-eats-PhDs_ workflow. You end up with protocols that are very hard to implement such as HTTP/2 and HTTP/3. You end up with Browser APIs that are damn hard to implement unless you're an operating system designer and a video game engineer.

In my mind what happened was that the web browsers became the space shuttle. It is fun and it takes us to the star but it is damn hard to work with and  you won't be building one in your backyard. You don't necessarily need to take a trip on a space shuttle to go buy groceries on the corner shop. FAANG want the stars and are dragging all of us into it when we actually need a safer and more powerful kickscooter. 

----

You can think of it as little boats. An enterprising person might build their own sailboat and have a ton of fun and travel many of the same seas as larger boats. Not all of them, but many. Now imagine if there was a spec saying that to be a boat you needed to be a transatlantic cruiser. All of a sudden, only few companies can build boats. Everything else is no longer a boat, right? 

----

That is what I think happened. We lost the web because we let those companies with infinitely deep pockets move the specs in the direction of their problems and not in the direction of what would make it more sustainable and easy to implement for everyone.

The way to change it is not do a _slash and burn_ but to fiddle with the user agents until they understand simpler stuff. Once the users reclaim user agents, other paths can evolve in parallel to the huge web.

# SSB Localization â™ˆ â™‰

![video:ahau_localization_min.webm](&J06f9hb3eZ83C7iQnYwj5gFgw3kBTjA4nkOJNN/eFP4=.sha256)

*Video with a concept for localization ih Ahau, with indigenous communities from the Brazilian territory in mind*

I've been trying to on-board my local community as well as other peers from Latin America into SSB for the past 3 years. The biggest block I've found has been the English language, as SSB's content to non-english speakers makes no sense. It would make a lot of sense that every message had a `language` type, and messages could be filtered by the ones users select.

Working with #ahau, which is the codebase I'm most familiar with, I built this really crude proof-of-concept for onboarding based on language. For Ahau, which has indigenous peoples as primary users, language is one of the most crucial aspects connecting to one's identity. And most indigenous cultures, at least in Latin America, are of oral culture, so it makes sense to take care to present information with images and sound.

This is very crude, and there are still english sentences and words that needs to be translated into icons. The idea with this is just to start a conversation that I feel is very important. This is crucial for Ahau, but also a must-have for other clients in order to give a better experience for non-english speakers, and if we really want #diversity, also for oral cultures.

Play with it at the `localization-concept` branch of [Ahau app](https://gitlab.com/ahau/whakapapa-ora/-/tree/localization-concept).  cc.: [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) [@Maui](@ood2kZqCeg7VCdVq2JAzxjtmZT9EXYVYNgAK4HRZMYs=.ed25519)

That makes sense, thanks [@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519)!

Since all houses have energy, I decided to make this much simpler version, consisting simply of an esp 8266, and the flow-meter inside one of the cases that I bought for [another project](%hMC/Ix/mnDvk0KYGcvXGo/Kt8UuegWYz6vB91RyhIKQ=.sha256).

![water_managment_prototype_AC.jpg](&0yCquhPsWR1dSO0znj0WbV6JunfEe0KviKBO3FiSp4A=.sha256)

The only thing missing I believe is a [check valve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Check_valve), which is necessary for the water to not flow in the inverse direction.

But it was enough to start the most difficult part of the project: the social part.

Lately there has been a bit of a water-war going on, where the people who live at the highest part of the village aren't getting any water flow, the reason being that we at the bottom are over-using it. There's a valve that stops the water from flowing to the low part of the village, and people have been turning it on and off without any real conversation going on.... Kinda sad.

One neighbor from the top part started being vocal about the issue, so I presented the prototype to him, and asked if he would like to test it at his house, as a way to collect data about the water issue and make it public thru the portal being built by #rede-moinho. All his relatives are visiting, so he asked for some time so that they can decide collectively. Hopefully we'll start testing soon.

# âœ¨ Fafi Browser new features teaser âœ¨

![video:2020-09-23_16-43-36.mp4](&QTZLSrcviIlwKsHsx5UJCZGR7rXO/2kiuuUC+2BG8Pk=.sha256)

This is a quick sneak peek video on some new features I'm building for Fafi 0.10.

* Preferences
* Bookmarks

Fafi is primarily a #gemini browser but it knows a trick or two regarding other protocols and file formats ðŸ˜¸

----

The bookmarks system is quite cute. It uses a hash table to hold the bookmarks. The keys are the URLs which are duplicated in the value as well. I set it like that because it makes it easier to update a bookmark than if it was a list and I had to iterate over it to find which record I needed to update.

```lisp
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; BOOKMARKS SYSTEM
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(define bookmarks-file (build-path data-folder "bookmarks.rktd"))

(define bookmarks (make-parameter (make-hash)))

(serializable-struct bookmark
                     (url
                      title
                      subscribe
                      favourite
                      last-checksum
                      tags
                      notes)
                     #:mutable
                     #:transparent)

(define (make-bookmark url [title ""] [subscribe #f] [favourite #f] [last-checksum 0] [tags '()] [notes ""])
  (bookmark url title subscribe favourite last-checksum tags notes))

(define (add-bookmark b)
  (let ([bs (bookmarks)])
    (hash-set! bs (bookmark-url b) b)
    (save-bookmarks)))

(define (save-bookmarks)
  (let ([s (serialize (bookmarks))])
    (with-output-to-file bookmarks-file
      (lambda () (write s))
      #:exists 'replace)))

(define (load-bookmarks)
  (let ([bs (if (file-exists? bookmarks-file)
                (with-input-from-file bookmarks-file
                  (lambda () (deserialize (read))))
                (make-hash))])
    (bookmarks bs)))
                      
```

That is the full code of the bookmark implementation.

Planetary and the #scuttlebutt protocol weâ€™re using is part of the emerging decentralized web (#dweb). Itâ€™s a bit ironic since the original web, [xanadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Xanadu) was decentralized, and so is the [world wide web](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web). For the fun of it, and to better our chances of getting connections I've been looking at [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JeUexihrKZQ) on how to make [ground plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_plane) antennas for 915mhz.

- 1x Copper (?) rods (usually used for soldering): **R$1,00** (0,25 USD each)
- 10x [N type female chassi mount](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1477138892-5x-114540-conector-tipo-n-fmea-base-quadrada-antena-rural-_JM): **R$ 240,00** (4,5 USD each)
- 10x [N type male / SMA male cables](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1662569225-kit-10-pc-cabo-de-descida-rgc-58-n-macho-sma-macho-010-mt-_JM): **R$ 332,00** (6,00 USD each)
